text.headline: Airborne/Aerosol: Old problem, new challenge!
text.text:
SARS-CoV-2 transmission: a inconsistency/ambiguity?
No authorities have admitted airborne transmission yet.
But all national and international authorities recommended maintaining good ventilation. If not airborne, why ventilate? - Yuguo Li

text.headline: Fresh air known to be important for army medical camps
text.text:
As long ago as 1753, Pringle, a doctor, studied medical army camp hospitals. He found that fresh air was important to stop disease spread.

post (@jmcrookston).

media.caption: Modern surgical mask Ben Frankin would've worn if he could

text.headline: Ben Franklin knew the score!
text.text:
Writeup: Dr Benjamin Franklin is seemingly predicting airborne viruses responsible for influenza and others associated with the common cold, and drawing a connection to becoming clinically ill with poor dietary choices (2017 writeup; see also Benjamin Franklin Would Get Social Distancing).

He also said in 1785 'I am persuaded that no common Air from without, is so unwholesome as the Air within a close Room, that has been often breath'd and not changed.'.

Find this book here

media.caption: Fodere - Lecons sur les epidemies (1828).

text.headline: Fresh air again referred to as important
text.text:
Fodere, in his treatise Lecons sur les epidemies, noted that fresh air in hospitals was important. Part of the text in this picture reads 'Make hospitals well isolated, well aired, with many air currents produced by ventilators and don't fill it with a large number of ill patients ...'

post here (@jmcrookston)

text.text: Chaumont FD: "On the theory of ventilation: an attempt to establish a positive basis for the calculation of the amount of fresh air required for an inhabited air-space". Via @mdc_martinus

text.headline: Charles Chapin knew scarlet fever was occasionally airborne
text.text:
Charles Chapin, who would later promote that most transmission was droplet borne, appreciated that scarlet fever could occasionally infect someone on the second floor of a house from the first - it was therefore airborne.

His book.

post here (@jmcrookston)

media.caption: Charles Chapin MD - Sources and modes of infection (1910)

text.headline: Chapin proposed that pathogens live in our bodies and are transmitted from person to person
text.text: Charles Chapin, medical doctor in Rhode Island, proposed in his groundbreaking book the radical notion that pathogens don't live long outside the body and were therefore transmitted person to person, and not simply freely floating in the air (miasma theory). He focussed therefore on stopping chains of transmission. Because he saw most transmission happening at short-range, which he called 'close contact', he suggested it was reasonable to him that this meant diseases were transmitted by droplets. He is wrong about this last part but the rest was brilliant. As an aside, he did not think fomites account for much transmission.

media.caption: Wells curves for different relative humidity

text.headline: W. F. Wells founding the droplet nuclei science in 1934
text.text: Wells thought that droplets smaller than a certain size would quickly evaporate, leaving a dry residue that drifts in the air. Since droplets from an infected person may contain infectious bacteria or viruses, these processes influence transmission of respiratory diseases

media.caption: clip from study

text.headline: Strep is airborne
text.text: Study finds that Streptococcal 'Strep' infections can happen in enclosed spaces. This disease is caused by a bacteria not a viruses. That is important because they are bigger in size, and convention wisdom said they could stay afloat in the air. See thread by @jmcrookston.

text.text: Richard L. Riley - first hand account of 1962 proof by Riley, Mills, O'Grady, Sultan, Willstadt, Shivpuri, and Wells: 'Infectiousness of air from a tuberculosis ward'. That study: here

text.headline: Airborne infection: Flu too
text.text: Riley studied the airborne nature of respiratory diseases in the middle of the 20th century, and published many times. See also a COVID19 era article on Riley.

text.headline: MEDICAL REVIEWS: "Coronaviruses"
text.text: ... It is therefore probable that human coronaviruses can be spread by aerosol as well as by large droplet. Aerosol transmission has actually been documented in poultry by the agent of avian infectious bronchitis.

text.headline: Study: Viruses And Indoor Air Pollution
text.text: "Microbiologic and epidemiologic data have shown that a number of viruses may contaminate the air of rooms and be capable of initiating disease in those who inhale them. However, with the exception of lymphocytic choriomeningitis virus, all are viruses transmitted from person to person." See @jmcrookston tweet.

text.headline: Study: Influenza Virus Aerosols in Human Exhaled Breath
text.text: Results: We detected influenza virus RNA in the coarse fraction (particles greater than 5 µm) collected from 11% (4 of 37 volunteers) while wearing surgical masks and from 43% (16 of 37) while not wearing a mask.

media.caption:
Modified Andersen Sampler used to collect viral RNA
in expelled particles produced on breathing and coughing

text.headline: Respiratory Virus RNA Is Detectable in Airborne and Droplet Particles
text.text: By using viral RNA as a marker of virus presence, findings in this study show many symptomatic individuals produce both small and large particles on both breathing and coughing, and that hRV and parainfluenza viruses may be present in both small and large particles. Given that airborne-sized and droplet-sized particles contain viral RNA, the use of droplet precautions exclusively may be insufficient to protect healthcare workers from exposure to virus in airborne-sized particles

text.headline: Article: Flu breath: sick people can spread the flu virus just by breathing
text.text: CDC Canada: A person infected with the flu who's not even coughing still emits fine aerosolized particles in their breath by simply sitting there, breathing and talking. Dr Don Milton: "We were seeing lots of virus — maybe a thousand particles in some cases in a half an hour.". See also umd.edu article
